So, for example, if plants give out X calories, mice might get around 0.9X, and skunks could get another 0.9 of that, which would be 0.81X, and so on. The question is asking how much energy the wolf gets directly from the clover plants. From what I recall, it states that each level of trophic food chain (like from plants to mice to skunks to wolves) loses approximately 90% of its energy at each step because about 10% is transferred to the next level. So, for example, if plants give out X calories, mice might get around 0.9X, and skunks could get another 0.9 of that, which would be 0.81X, and so on. The question is asking how much energy the wolf gets directly from the clover plants. Since the wolf is at the highest trophic level here—maybe as a consumer—the most efficient energy transfer would occur when the wolf takes all the energy from the previous level before being eaten by something else. But since there's no mention of other predators after the wolf, I think we can assume that the wolf receives all the energy available at the point where it was taken by the skunk.
